Primary Storage â€¢ Operated directly by CPU (e.g., main memory, cache memory). â€¢ Provides fast access to data. â€¢ Limited storage capacity compared to enterprise database needs. â€¢ Expensive relative to disks. â€¢ Volatile â€“ data lost during power failure or system crash. Secondary Storage â€¢ Primary medium for online storage of enterprise databases. â€¢ Traditionally magnetic disks used. â€¢ Flash memory (SSDs) increasingly popular. â€¢ Non-volatile and permanent storage. â€¢ Suitable for large databases. Tertiary Storage â€¢ Optical disks (CD-ROM, DVD) and tapes used for archiving. â€¢ Removable, offline storage. â€¢ Provides large capacity at lower cost. â€¢ Slower access compared to primary/secondary. â€¢ Data must be copied to primary storage before CPU can process. Memory Hierarchies and Storage Devices Memory Hierarchy Concept â€¢ Data resides in multiple storage levels â†’ speed vs. cost trade-off. â€¢ High-speed memory = expensive, low capacity (e.g., cache). â€¢ Low-speed memory = cheaper, very high capacity (e.g., tapes). Primary Storage â–ª Cache Memory (SRAM) âœ“ Fastest, most expensive. âœ“ Used by CPU for prefetching & pipelining. â–ª DRAM (Main Memory) âœ“ Cheaper, larger than cache. âœ“ Volatile & slower than SRAM. âœ“ Holds program instructions & data. âœ“ Now available in GB to hundreds of GB range. âœ“ Main-memory databases possible â†’ useful for real-time applications (e.g., telephone switching). Why stored on magnetic disks (secondary storage): â€¢ Databases are too large for main memory. â€¢ Disk storage is non-volatile, unlike volatile main memory. â€¢ Cheaper cost per unit compared to primary storage. Emerging Technologies: â€¢ SSDs may replace magnetic disks in some cases. â€¢ Future DBs may use different hierarchy levels (main memory â†’ SSD â†’ tape jukebox). â€¢ But magnetic disks expected to remain dominant for large DBs. Other Storage Media: â€¢ Magnetic tapes â€“ cheap, used for backup/archiving. â€¢ Require operator/auto-loader; offline access (slower). â€¢ Disks â€“ online, direct access anytime. Storage Organization of Databases Physical Database Design: â€¢ DB designers/DBA must know advantages/disadvantages of storage methods. â€¢ DBMS offers multiple organization techniques. â€¢ Choice depends on application requirements. Data Access: â€¢ Applications usually need only a small portion of DB at a time. â€¢ Process: Disk â†’ Main Memory â†’ CPU â†’ (back to Disk if modified). â€¢ Data organized as files of records (entities, attributes, relationships). File Organization Techniques: â€¢ Heap (Unordered file): Records appended without order. â€¢ Sorted (Sequential file): Ordered by a field (sort key). â€¢ Hashed file: Uses hash function on a hash key. â€¢ B-trees (and variants): Tree-based structure for efficient access. Secondary (Auxiliary) Organization: â€¢ Provides efficient access via alternate fields. â€¢ Implemented mostly as indexes Secondary Storage Devices (a) A single-sided disk with read/write hardware. (b) A disk pack with read/write hardware. Secondary Storage Devices Different sectororganizations on disk. (a) Sectors subtendinga fixed angle.(b) Sectors maintaining a uniform recording density Techniques to Make Disk Data Access More Efficient 1.Buffering of Data â€¢Balances speed mismatch between CPU and slow HDD. â€¢Uses memory buffers to hold data temporarily. â€¢Double buffering improves throughput. 2.Proper Organization of Data on Disk â€¢Store related data in contiguous blocks/cylinders. â€¢Reduces arm movement and seek time. 3.Reading Data Ahead of Request (Prefetching) â€¢Reads additional consecutive blocks even if not requested. â€¢Works well for sequential access.Not effective for random access. 4.Proper Scheduling of I/O Requests â€¢Organizes block access to minimize arm movement. â€¢Elevator algorithm (SCAN) â†’ services requests in one direction, then reverses. 5.Use of Log Disks for Writes â€¢Dedicated disk (or area) used to store writes sequentially. â€¢Eliminates seek time. â€¢Improves write performance but adds cost. 6.Use of SSDs/Flash for Recovery â€¢SSD/flash used as fast non-volatile buffer for updates. â€¢Prevents update loss in case of system crash. â€¢Data later written to HDD during idle times or when buffer is full. Secondary Storage Devices Hardware Description of Disk Devices Magnetic Disks (HDDs): âœ“ Store large amounts of data. âœ“ Basic unit: bit (0 or 1 via magnetization). âœ“ Bits grouped into bytes (8 bits = 1 character, most common). âœ“ Capacity = number of bytes it can store (modern disks â†’ hundreds of GBs to TBs). Disk Structure: âœ“ Made of thin circular magnetic material, protected by cover. âœ“ Single-sided (one surface used) or double-sided (both surfaces). âœ“ Disks assembled into disk packs (multiple disks/surfaces). âœ“ Common form factors: 3.5 inch, 2.5 inch. âœ“ Data stored in tracks (concentric circles). âœ“ Tracks of same diameter across surfaces = cylinder â†’ faster retrieval if data stored in one cylinder. Secondary Storage Devices Tracks, Sectors, and Blocks: âœ“ Disk has thousands of tracks (up to ~152,000). âœ“ Each track divided into sectors (fixed, hard-coded). âœ“ Sector sizes: commonly 512 bytes. âœ“ Tracks also divided into blocks/pages (set during formatting). âœ“ Typical block sizes: 512 bytes â€“ several KB. âœ“ Several blocks = cluster (transferred as a unit). Read/Write Mechanism: âœ“ Performed by disk head attached to mechanical arm. âœ“ Multiple surfaces â†’ multiple heads, controlled together by actuator motor. âœ“ Disk rotates continuously (speed: 5,400 â€“ 15,000 rpm). âœ“ Fixed-head disks: one head per track â†’ faster, but costly. âœ“ Movable-head disks: common, cheaper. Secondary Storage Devices Disk Interfaces: âœ“ Older: SCSI (Small Computer System Interface). âœ“ Modern: SATA (Serial ATA) and SAS (Serial Attached SCSI). âœ“ SATA: common in PCs (1.5 â€“ 6 Gbps). âœ“ SAS: used in servers, better IOPS (Input/Output per second). âœ“ Drive sizes: âœ“ 3.5-inch: up to 8 TB, 7,200â€“10,000 rpm. âœ“ 2.5-inch: up to 1.2 TB, up to 15,000 rpm. Disk Access Times: âœ“ Seek Time: Time to move head to correct track (3â€“10 ms). âœ“ Rotational Delay (Latency): Time for block to rotate under head (depends on rpm; e.g., ~2 ms at 15,000 rpm). âœ“ Block Transfer Time: Time to actually transfer data (smaller). âœ“ Total = Seek Time + Rotational Delay + Transfer Time. âœ“ Access time: ~9 â€“ 60 ms. âœ“ Contiguous block transfer much faster (saves seek/latency). Secondary Storage Devices Performance Bottleneck: âœ“ Disk I/O is slower compared to CPU/main memory speeds. âœ“ Hence, file organization techniques try to minimize block transfers. âœ“ Goal: store related info in contiguous blocks to reduce delays. Secondary Storage Devices Performance Bottleneck: âœ“ Disk I/O is slower compared to CPU/main memory speeds. âœ“ Hence, file organization techniques try to minimize block transfers. âœ“ Goal: store related info in contiguous blocks to reduce delays. Placing File Records on Disk â€¢ Data in a database is stored as records organized into files. â€¢ A record: a collection of related data values (fields) representing an entity. â€¢ A record type: defines the fields and their data types. â€¢ Files contain sequences of records; placement affects performance Each record describes an entity (e.g., EMPLOYEE). â€¢ Fields have data types: âœ“ Numeric: integer, long, floating point âœ“ String: fixed-length or variable-length âœ“ Boolean: 0/1 or TRUE/FALSE âœ“ Date/Time: fixed-size format Example in C: struct employee { char name[30]; char ssn[9]; int salary; int job_code; char department[20]; }; File Types Large Data Items âœ“ BLOB (Binary Large Object): stores images, audio, video, or free text. âœ“ Usually stored separately from the main record. âœ“ Example: CLOB (Character Large Object) for free text. âœ“ Alternatives: âž¢ Store as files in file systems âž¢ Store as files managed by database âž¢ Break into pieces and store in multiple tuples in separate relation â–ª PostgreSQL TOAST â€¢ Fixed-length records: all records same size. â€¢ Variable-length records: record sizes differ due to: 1. Variable-length fields (e.g., Name field) 2. Repeating fields (multi-valued) 3. Optional fields 4. Mixed record types File Types- Fixed-Length Records âœ“ All fields have fixed sizes â†’ predictable record length. âœ“ Example: EMPLOYEE record = 71 bytes âœ“ Easy to locate field values by byte offset. âœ“ Limitation: wasted space for optional or repeating fields. âœ“ Simple approach: â€¢ Store record i starting from byte n * (i â€“ 1), where n is the size of each record. â€¢ Record access is simple but records may cross blocks â–ª Modification: do not allow records to cross block boundaries File Types- Fixed-Length Records â–ª Deletion of record i: alternatives: â€¢ move records i + 1, . . ., n to i, . . . , n â€“ 1 â€¢ move record n to i â€¢ do not move records, but link all free records on a free list Record 3 deleted File Types- Fixed-Length Records â–ª Deletion of record i: alternatives: â€¢ move records i + 1, . . ., n to i, . . . , n â€“ 1 â€¢ move record n to i â€¢ do not move records, but link all free records on a free list Record 3 deleted and replaced by record 11 File Types- Fixed-Length Records â–ª Deletion of record i: alternatives: â€¢ move records i + 1, . . ., n to i, . . . , n â€“ 1 â€¢ move record n to i â€¢ do not move records, but link all free records on a free list File Types- Variable-Length Records âœ“ Field lengths can vary; require special handling: â–ª Separator characters (e.g., ?, %, $) between fields â–ª Field-name/value pairs for optional fields â–ª Field-type/value pairs for efficiency â–ª Repeating fields: separators between values, terminator at end âœ“ Variable-length records arise in database systems in several ways: â€¢ Storage of multiple record types in a file. â€¢ Record types that allow variable lengths for one or more fields such as strings (varchar) â€¢ Record types that allow repeating fields (used in some older data models). âœ“ Attributes are stored in order âœ“ Variable length attributes represented by fixed size (offset, length), with actual data stored after all fixed length attributes âœ“ Null values represented by null-value bitmap File Types- Variable-Length Records Slotted Page Structure Null values represented by null-value bitmap File Types- Variable-Length Records â–ª Slotted page header contains: â€¢ number of record entries â€¢ end of free space in the block â€¢ location and size of each record â–ª Records can be moved around within a page to keep them contiguous with no empty space between them; entry in the header must be updated. â–ª Pointers should not point directly to record â€” instead they should point to the entry for the record in header. Record Blocking and Spanned vs Unspanned Records Disk Storage and File Organization âœ“ Disk blocks are the unit of data transfer between disk and memory. âœ“ Each block can store multiple records if the block size (B) > record size (R). âœ“ Blocking factor (bfr): number of records per block âœ“ Unused space per block: Record Blocking and Spanned vs Unspanned Records Spanned Records : âœ“ Part of a record can be stored on one block and the rest on another. âœ“ Requires a pointer to the next block containing the remainder. âœ“ Advantages: â–ª Utilizes unused space efficiently â–ª Useful for records larger than a block âœ“ Applicable to: Fixed-length or variable-length records when record size > block size Record Blocking and Spanned vs Unspanned Records UnSpanned Records : âœ“ Records cannot cross block boundaries.. âœ“ Requires a pointer to the next block containing the remainder. âœ“ Advantages: â€¢ Each record starts at a known position within a block â€¢ Simplifies record processing âœ“ Applicable to: Fixed-length records where block size > record size Record Blocking and Spanned vs Unspanned Records Choosing Between Spanned and Unspanned Organization Type Pros Cons Use Case Spanned Efficient space usage More complex processing Large or variable-length records Unspanned Simple processing Wasted space in partially filled blocks Fixed-length small records File Block Allocation Techniques Efficiently store file blocks on disk for fast access and expansion. Common techniques: 1. Contiguous Allocation âœ“ Blocks stored in consecutive disk locations âœ“ Pros: Fast sequential read (double buffering) âœ“ Cons: Difficult to expand file 2. Linked Allocation âœ“ Each block contains a pointer to the next block âœ“ Pros: Easy to expand file âœ“ Cons: Slow sequential read File Block Allocation Techniques 3. Combined/Clustered Allocation o Groups of consecutive blocks (clusters) are linked o Clusters also called file segments or extents 4. Indexed Allocation o One or more index blocks store pointers to file blocks o Often combined with other techniques File Headers â€¢ Metadata about the file needed for access. â€¢ Contents of a file header: âž¢ Disk addresses of file blocks âž¢ Record format description â€¢ Fixed-length unspanned records: field lengths & field order â€¢ Variable-length records: field-type codes, separator characters, record type codes â€¢ Programs use header information to locate and read records efficiently. Searching Records Using File Headers â€¢ When searching for a record: âž¢ Copy one or more blocks into main memory buffers âž¢ Use file header info to identify record location â€¢ Without block address info: linear search through all blocks is needed âž¢ Time-consuming for large fisles â€¢ Goal of file organization: Avoid linear search and minimize full file scans Operations on Files Two main categories: 1. Retrieval operations: Locate records without changing data. 2. Update operations: Change data by inserting, deleting, or modifying records. â€¢ Selection condition (filtering) used to locate records: â€¢ Example: (Ssn = '123456789') or (Salary >= 30000 AND Department = 'Research') â€¢ Complex conditions are decomposed into simple conditions for locating records. Record-at-a-Time Operations Operations applied to a single record rather than multiple records simultaneously. â€¢ Open: Prepare file for access, allocate buffers, read file header. â€¢ Reset: Move file pointer to beginning. â€¢ Find / Locate: Search for first record satisfying condition, load block into buffer. â€¢ Read / Get: Copy current record into program variable, may advance pointer. â€¢ FindNext: Locate next record satisfying condition. â€¢ Delete: Remove current record from file. â€¢ Modify: Change fields of current record. â€¢ Insert: Add new record into file block and update disk. â€¢ Close: Release buffers and complete file access. Scan Operation and Set-at-a- Time Operations Scan Operation â€¢ Combines Find, FindNext, and Read into a single operation. â€¢ Returns first or next record satisfying a condition. â€¢ Simplifies sequential access for retrieval operations. Set-at-a-Time Operations Operate on multiple records at once: â€¢ FindAll: Retrieve all records satisfying a condition. â€¢ Find n: Retrieve first n records satisfying a condition. â€¢ FindOrdered: Retrieve records in a specified order. â€¢ Reorganize: Reorder records (e.g., by sorting) for efficiency. File Organization vs Access Method and Considerations for File Organization âœ“ File organization: How data is physically stored in records, blocks, and structures. âœ“ Access method: Set of operations applied to a file (e.g., Find, Scan). âœ“ Multiple access methods can operate on a single file organization. âœ“ Indexed access requires an index; not all methods are universally applicable âž¢ Expected usage patterns influence organization: âž¢ Static files: mostly read-only, few updates âž¢ Dynamic files: frequent insert, delete, modify operations âž¢ Optimizing for common search conditions improves efficiency Organization of Records in Files â–ª Heap â€“ record can be placed anywhere in the file where there is space â–ª Sequential â€“ store records in sequential order, based on the value of the search key of each record â–ª In a multitable clustering file organization records of several different relations can be stored in the same file â€¢ Motivation: store related records on the same block to minimize I/O â–ª B+-tree file organization â€¢ Ordered storage even with inserts/deletes â–ª Hashing â€“ a hash function computed on search key; the result specifies in which block of the file the record should be placed Heap File Organization â€¢ Heap file = simplest and most basic file organization. â€¢ Records are stored in the order they are inserted (no sorting). â€¢ New records are appended to the end of the file. â€¢ Commonly used for: â–ª Collecting and storing records for future use. â–ª Supporting secondary indexes for faster access. â–ª Easy insertion, but searching and deletion are less efficient. Insertion Very efficient operation: â€¢ Copy the last disk block into buffer. â€¢ Add new record into buffer. â€¢ Write block back to disk. â€¢ File header keeps address of the last block. â€¢ Minimal overhead compared to other organizations. Heap File Organization Searching â€¢No ordering of records â†’ requires linear search. â€¢Must scan block by block until condition is met. â€¢Average cost: â€¢ If one record satisfies condition â†’ ~b/2 blocks must be checked (where b = number of blocks). â€¢ If no records (or multiple records) match â†’ all b blocks must be scanned. â€¢Searching is expensive for large files. Deletion Two main methods: 1. Physical Deletion â–ª Find the block, load into buffer, delete record, write back. â–ª Leaves unused space in the block. â–ª Deleting many records wastes storage space. 2. Logical Deletion (Deletion Marker) â–ª Add an extra bit/byte to mark record as deleted. â–ª Valid records are those without deletion marker. â–ª Both methods require periodic reorganization to reclaim unused space. Heap File Organization Heap File Organization Reorganization â€¢ Required when many deletions have occurred. â€¢ Process: â€¢ Sequentially access all blocks. â€¢ Pack valid records together, remove deleted ones. â€¢ Fill blocks to full capacity again. â€¢ Alternative approach: â€¢ Reuse deleted record space during new insertions. â€¢ Requires bookkeeping to track free space. Heap - Record Organization Options Spanned vs. Unspanned Organization: â–ª Spanned: Records can span across multiple blocks. â–ª Unspanned: Each record fits entirely within a single block. Fixed-Length vs. Variable-Length Records: Fixed: Easier to manage and access. Variable: More flexible, but modification may require deletion + reinsertion. Sorting records: To read in sorted order, file must be copied and sorted. Sorting is expensive for large files â†’ external sorting is used. Heap File Organization Relative (Direct) Files â€¢ Special type of unordered file with fixed-length records + unspanned blocks. â€¢ Allows direct access to records by position: â€¢ If file has r records numbered 0â€¦r-1, and block has bfr (blocking factor) records: â€¢ Record i is located in block âŽ£i / bfrâŽ¦ â€¢ Position = (i mod bfr) in that block. â€¢ Provides direct positional access (efficient). â€¢ Still does not help with conditional searches. â€¢ Useful for building access paths like indexes. Heap File Organization Need for Free-Space Tracking â€¢ Since records can go into any available free space, the system must be able to quickly find blocks with enough empty space. â€¢ If we scan every block to find free space, it becomes very expensive. â€¢ Solution: use a Free-Space Map. Free-Space Map â€¢ A free-space map is an array with one entry per block in the file. â€¢ Each entry is only a few bits or a byte, recording the fraction of the block that is free. Example: Using 3 bits per block. Value Ã· 8 gives the fraction of free space. If value = 4, it means half (4/8 = 0.5) of the block is free. Similarly, â€¢ FSM = 0 â†’ 0% free â†’ Block is full. â€¢ FSM = 4 â†’ 50% free â†’ 4 KB free in an 8 KB block. â€¢ FSM = 6 â†’ 75% free â†’ 6 KB free in an 8 KB block. â€¢ FSM = 7 â†’ 100% free â†’ Entire block is empty. Heap File Organization Second-Level Free-Space Map â€¢ For very large files, scanning the entire first-level map is still expensive. â€¢ A second-level map is created, where each entry stores the maximum free space value of a group of first-level entries. â€¢Example: â€¢ Each second-level entry summarizes 4 first-level entries. â€¢ This allows the system to quickly locate a region where enough free space exists, and then check only a few blocks in detail. Each summarizes 4 blocks by storing the maximum free space value among them. â€¢ Arrows show how groups of 4 blocks are linked to one second-level entry. attribute to set of attributes used to look up records in a file. â—¼ An index file consists of records (called index entries) of the form â—¼ Index files are typically much smaller than the original file â—¼ Two basic kinds of indices: âž¢ Ordered indices: search keys are stored in sorted order âž¢ Hash indices: search keys are distributed uniformly across â€œbucketsâ€ using a â€œhash functionâ€. search-key pointer Index Evaluation Metrics â—¼ Access types supported efficiently. âž¢records with a specified value in the attribute âž¢or records with an attribute value falling in a specified range of values. â—¼ Access time â—¼ Insertion time â—¼ Deletion time â—¼ Space overhead Ordered Indices Indexing techniques evaluated on basis of: â—¼ In an ordered index, index entries are stored sorted on the search key value. E.g., author catalog in library. â—¼ Primary index: in a sequentially ordered file, the index whose search key specifies the sequential order of the file. âž¢Also called clustering index- defined on non-key ordering field (multiple records can share value). âž¢The search key of a primary index is usually but not necessarily the primary key. â—¼ Secondary index: an index whose search key specifies an order different from the sequential order of the file. Also called non-clustering index. â—¼ Index-sequential file: ordered sequential file with a primary index. Ordered Indices Indexing techniques evaluated on basis of: â—¼ In an ordered index, index entries are stored sorted on the search key value. E.g., author catalog in library. â—¼ Primary index: in a sequentially ordered file, the index whose search key specifies the sequential order of the file. âž¢Also called clustering index- defined on non-key ordering field (multiple records can share value). âž¢The search key of a primary index is usually but not necessarily the primary key. â—¼ Secondary index: an index whose search key specifies an order different from the sequential order of the file. Also called non-clustering index. â—¼ Index-sequential file: ordered sequential file with a primary index.
